sharing.title: The Senate voted to save net neutrality
sharing.description:
The U.S. Senate voted to save net neutrality. Join millions of other every day
Americans demanding freedom on the Internet in the House of Representatives.

redalert.title: Red Alert for Net Neutrality
redalert.intro_html: BREAKING NEWS: The Senate voted to save net neutrality. Now we need the House of Representatives to do the same, or else the FCC will let ISPs like Comcast and Verizon ruin the internet with throttling, censorship and unnecessary fees. Write your lawmakers now!
redalert.tweet_text:
The U.S. Senate voted to save net neutrality. Join millions of other every day
Americans demanding freedom on the Internet in the House of Representatives.

stats.title: Congress, are you listening?
stats.body_html: Voters from across the political spectrum agree they don't want their cable company to control what they see and do online. The FCC's reckless repeal has sparked an unprecedented backlash. The numbers below are only what we know about through BattleForTheNet.com and partners. These are constituents calling on lawmakers to stop the FCC and save net neutrality:

participants.title: Participants
participants.body_html: Below is a list of notable websites, companies, and organizations who have confirmed their participation in the RED ALERT action.

what.title: What's happening?
what.body_html: Starting on May 9th the Internet went on Red Alert contact Congress in support of net neutrality ‚Ä¶ and it worked. The Senate voted to block the FCC‚Äôs repeal of net neutrality. Because we still need the House of Representatives to block the FCC‚Äôs repeal, you can still put your website or social media accounts on Red Alert to raise awareness. Click to jump to instructions for how to join with your website or on social media.

join.title: How to put your site on RED ALERT
join.body_html:
Add our RED ALERT widget to your site. It's a small (but powerful!) notice to your site's users that something BIG is happening with net neutrality. Users can expand the widget and contact Congress by selecting "TAKE ACTION" or close the widget by pressing the "Close" button.

Try it out

Pretty cool, right? Simply add this line of JavaScript to any page on your site to join the RED ALERT campaign:

<script src="https://redalert.battleforthenet.com/widget.js" async></script>

The widget will appear on your page just like you see it here:

When users click to TAKE ACTION, the widget will expand to display an urgent message to contact Congress in support of net neutrality:

If you'd like to configure the appearance or change the location of the widget on your web pages, just visit our GitHub page to learn how.

Please feel free to create your own custom way to drive awareness of this important issue and encourage your users to contact Congress. But whatever you do, make sure it's epic. THIS is the moment to fight!

banners.title: Post banner ads on your site
banners.body_html:
Do you run a site or blog? Use these banner ads to get the word out on net neutrality. Click here to see a bunch of different ad sizes and styles.

Feeling creative? Make something yourself and submit it for other sites to use by emailing us at team@fightforthefuture.org.

social.title: Put your social media accounts on Red Alert
social.body_html:
If you‚Äôre active on social media, have a video channel, or moderate an online forum, put your small piece of the Internet on RED ALERT by changing your profile and banner images, and scheduling frequent posts linking to BattleForTheNet.com where people can take action. Click here for a giant folder of content you can use. Then click here to see ideas for blog posts, emails, tweets and more.

Avatar images

Twitter header images

Facebook header images

Instagram Story

events.title: Events
events.body_html: People and small businesses all over America are vigorously defending net neutrality by staging protests and organizing events at Congressional offices. Check out the map below to view events in your area, or view our full events page here.

index.document_title: Join the Battle for Net Neutrality
index.title: Congress can still save net neutrality
index.intro_html: The FCC just officially gutted the open internet. Now your cable company can scam you for more money, censor websites, and slow down online content. But Congress can still stop this. We already won in the Senate. Contact your House reps now!

form.business_owner_label: Are you a business owner who supports net neutrality?
form.default_letter:
Last December's FCC vote to destroy the net neutrality protections cannot stand.

I‚Äôm calling on you to work with your colleagues to use the Congressional Review Act to pass a "resolution of disapproval" reversing the FCC's vote.

The FCC's December decision willfully ignored the outcry of tens of millions of people, and it abdicated the FCC's responsibility to protect the internet from ISP blocking and discrimination. The FCC has injured our economy and free speech in just one action, all without so much as a single public hearing.

We need members of Congress to stand up for the open internet and for the digital rights of their constituents now. Please co-sponsor, sign the discharge petition for, and vote for the CRA Resolution of Disapproval that would overturn the FCC's December "Restoring Internet Freedom" vote.

Thank you.

join.title: Net neutrality was repealed, but the fight has just begun
join.body_html:
The FCC‚Äôs repeal of net neutrality officially kicked in on June 11th. Going forward, Internet providers like Comcast will legally be allowed to censor websites, block apps and services, and charge us extra fees to access online content. The Internet as we know it won‚Äôt suddenly end. But with each second that passes until net neutrality is restored, it will be slowly dying.

People are angry. And rightly so. We need to channel that anger productively and flood House lawmakers with calls and emails demanding that they use the Congressional Review Act (CRA) to overrule the FCC.

So take whatever corner of the Internet that you control ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs a major platform or a personal instagram account ‚Äî and harness its reach to pressure Congress. Here‚Äôs how:

  1. Change your social media avatars and profile pics to help sound the alarm, there‚Äôs bunch of graphics in a shared folder here.
  2. If you make videos, consider making a video about net neutrality, or use our simple video bumper to help spread the word.
  3. Link back to BattleForTheNet.com whenever you can so people can easily contact their lawmakers.
  4. If you run a website or blog, deploy our updated widget to let your users contact Congress without ever leaving your site. You can see a demo here. There are also banners and ads of various sizes you can use here.

Users who take action will be able to send a letter to Congress from within the widget by entering their contact info. Users who close the widget won‚Äôt see it again for 24 hours. Try it out for yourself by clicking the button below:

Try it out

It‚Äôs easy to use. Simply add the line of code below to your website‚Äôs header. And don‚Äôt forget to visit our GitHub page to learn how to customize the widget for your site.

<script src="https://june11.battleforthenet.com/widget.js" async></script>

cra.title: Here‚Äôs how we get Congress to save net neutrality
cra.body_html:
Our elected officials in Congress can overrule the FCC and save net neutrality using the Congressional Review Act (CRA). But they‚Äôll only do it if we make them. The CRA resolution passed the Senate 52-47 in a historic upset. But now we‚Äôre fighting an uphill battle to get the House of Representatives to do the same. It‚Äôs not going to be easy, but if the whole Internet comes together to fight, we can win. Here‚Äôs how:

In the House, we‚Äôll need 218 lawmakers to sign on to a ‚Äúdischarge petition‚Äù in order to force a vote past leadership to the floor. That means we‚Äôll need to convince all the Democrats and about 25 Republicans to support the CRA. The clock is ticking‚Ää‚Äî if the CRA resolution doesn‚Äôt get a vote this year, it dies when the new Congress comes into session. We've done it before.


Here‚Äôs how we‚Äôll do it this time:

  • Flood them with calls and emails

    When millions of people call and email their representatives, Congress listens. That‚Äôs why we developed a widget that website owners can place on their site, giving their site‚Äôs users the opportunity to contact Congress. And we‚Äôve created art assets that will allow individuals to spread the word on powerful social media platforms.

  • In-district constituent pressure

    It‚Äôs important for lawmakers to see the people who support net neutrality. We‚Äôll help schedule in-person events, protests, meetings, and canvassing to mobilize constituencies (like veterans) that move republicans.

  • Mobilizing small businesses

    In Washington, money talks. So lawmakers listen to the small business owners in their districts because those business owners are vital to the local economy. We need to reach out to small business owners to ask them to sign our petition in support of net neutrality, then we hand-deliver this petition to our politicians.

stats.title:
We're making
Congress listen
stats.body_html:
Voters from across the political spectrum agree: they don't want their cable company to control what they see and do online. The FCC's reckless repeal of net neutrality has sparked an unprecedented backlash, as millions of Americans have contacted their lawmakers in protest. The numbers below represent actions taken through BattleForTheNet.com and its partners. Many more have taken action on other sites or contacted their lawmakers directly.

To help convince the House, contact congress now and add to these numbers.

scoreboard.title: View the Congressional Scoreboard
scoreboard.body_html:
We‚Äôre keeping track of who supports net neutrality ‚Ä¶ and who doesn‚Äôt. Now you can, too. Below you'll find a link to a list of your state's Senators and Representatives. The ones in green have signed a discharge petition in support of net neutrality, so let them know you appreciate their support. The ones in red need to be convinced, so let them know how important this issue is to you.

We already won in the Senate. Now we must win in the House. So please tweet and call your House Representatives.

wanted.title: Is your representative wanted?
wanted.body_html: The FCC killed net neutrality. But they didn‚Äôt act alone. Their accomplices are Team Cable, the members of Congress sitting idly by allowing the free and open Internet to be stolen from us. We can‚Äôt let them get away with it. So we made WANTED posters for every rep that‚Äôs helping the FCC get away with murder. Let‚Äôs make sure they have nowhere to hide ‚Äî put these up everywhere online: as your profile image, as a post, on your site, everywhere.

events.title: Attend an event in your area
events.body_html:
Want to make your voice heard? Check out the map below to find a protest or a meeting with a representative in your state. And if there are no events in your area, consider organizing one!

View Full Map

net-neutrality.title: What is net neutrality? Why does it matter?
net-neutrality.body_html:
Net neutrality is the principle that everyone should have access to websites and apps, preventing Internet providers like Comcast & Verizon from creating ‚Äúfast lanes,‚Äù censoring content, throttling traffic and even outright blocking access to their competitor's products. This principle has guided the world wide web from the beginning, and has been protected by federal policy under Republican AND Democrat leadership since the early 2000s.

Unfortunately, Internet providers ignored this policy and even actively sued the federal government to destroy net neutrality protections ‚Ä¶ and they won. Their anti-consumer practices finally convinced the FCC to issue the Open Internet Order as a last resort in 2015. But under new leadership, the FCC has removed these regulations, threatening to end the web as we know it.

Want to learn more? Watch these videos!

team-internet.title: We are Team Internet
team-internet.body_html: Members of Team Internet support free speech and free markets online through meaningful, enforceable net neutrality laws. We are millions of everyday Americans from across the political spectrum. We are thousands of small business owners. We are large corporations and powerful non-profits. Check out the list below to see who‚Äôs taken action to save net neutrality:

team-cable.title: They are Team Cable
team-cable.body_html: Team Cable wants to end net neutrality so they can control and tax the Internet. Team Cable lies about the effects of net neutrality on the free market and ignores blatant corruption in the regulatory process. If they get their way, we will all pay more money for worse Internet access. Independent voices will be stifled. And innovative start-ups will struggle to compete in the online marketplace.

california.title: California can still save net neutrality
california.body_html: Telecom giants like AT&T and Comcast tried everything to water down the best state level net neutrality bill in the country, California‚Äôs SB 822, but they failed. The bill has been restored and is now headed for a vote on the Assembly floor. But the ISPs are still lobbying fiercely to defeat it. Call the California Assembly right now and tell them to pass SB 822 and restore net neutrality!
california.share_description: After a corrupt lawmaker railroaded net neutrality protections, lawmakers need to hear from you.

index.intro_html: We need 218 votes in support of net neutrality to win in the House. We currently have 175, but we need 43 more. Enter your information below to see if your representative supports net neutrality, and learn what you can do to help.
